## <i class="bi bi-share"></i> Core Sharing Activities

Making research outputs accessible involves multiple interconnected practices.

::: {.orc-grid-feature}

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-database"></i> Data Archiving

Common practices:

- Depositing in appropriate repositories
- Comprehensive metadata documentation
- Appropriate licensing (CC0, CC BY)
- Long-term preservation planning
:::

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-code-square"></i> Code Publishing

Researchers typically:

- Publish to GitHub with documentation
- Archive releases on Zenodo
- Assign DOIs for citation
- Add open source licenses
:::

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-file-text"></i> Open Access

Paths to openness:

- Preprints and postprints
- Gold open access journals
- Institutional repositories
- Green self-archiving
:::

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-fingerprint"></i> Persistent Identifiers

Ensuring findability through:

- DOIs for data and code
- ORCID for researchers
- ROR IDs for institutions
- Funder identifiers
:::

:::

## <i class="bi bi-diagram-3"></i> Preservation & Sharing Strategies

Different research outputs require different sharing approaches and platforms.

::: {.panel-tabset}

### Data Sharing

Understanding when, where, and how to share research data.

::: {.orc-grid-feature}

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-shield-check"></i> FAIR Data

Making data findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable:

- Rich metadata with keywords
- Persistent identifiers (DOIs)
- Standard file formats
- Clear usage licenses
:::

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-globe"></i> Open Sharing

When data can be publicly shared:

- Discipline-specific repositories preferred
- General repositories (Zenodo, OSF)
- Complete anonymization required
- Comprehensive documentation
:::

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-lock"></i> Restricted Access

For sensitive data:

- Metadata-only publication
- Data Access Agreements
- Controlled access repositories
- Institutional secure storage
:::

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-search"></i> Repository Selection

Finding the right repository:

- Search [re3data.org](https://www.re3data.org/) for domain repositories
- Check journal requirements
- Consider long-term preservation
- Verify DOI assignment
:::

:::

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-clipboard-check"></i> Before Depositing Data</summary>

Essential steps:

- Complete anonymization of personal information
- README file with study description and methods
- Data dictionary with variable descriptions
- Appropriate license (CC0 or CC BY recommended)
- Ethics committee approval if required

::: {.callout-warning}
Consult your institution's data protection office before sharing human participant data.
:::

</details>

### Code Publishing

Making research code citable and reusable.

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-github"></i> GitHub to Zenodo Workflow</summary>

Standard workflow for citable code:

1. **Prepare Repository**: Add README, license, example data
2. **Link to Zenodo**: Enable integration via GitHub
3. **Create Release**: Tag version (e.g., v1.0.0)
4. **Obtain DOI**: Zenodo automatically archives and assigns DOI
5. **Cite**: Include DOI in manuscript

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="mortarboard"}
## Learn More: Code Publishing

[Code Publishing Tutorial](https://lmu-osc.github.io/code-publishing/) (2.5h) - Complete guide to publishing research code
:::

</details>

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-shield-exclamation"></i> Security Checklist</summary>

Before publishing code:

- Remove API keys, passwords, credentials
- Remove personal or participant data
- Review entire git history
- Add simulated data if needed
- Document dependencies clearly

</details>

### Open Access

Maximizing accessibility of publications.

::: {.orc-grid-2col}

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-unlock"></i> Green Open Access

Free self-archiving:

- Preprints before peer review
- Postprints after acceptance
- Institutional repositories
- No publication fees
:::

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-journal-check"></i> Gold Open Access

Publisher open access:

- Immediate open license publication
- Usually requires APC payment
- Check institutional agreements
- Request CC BY license
:::

:::

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-file-earmark-arrow-up"></i> Understanding Versions</summary>

**Preprint**: Manuscript before peer review

- Upload at submission for early feedback
- Platforms: bioRxiv, medRxiv, arXiv, OSF Preprints

**Postprint**: Accepted manuscript (author's version)

- Upload after acceptance
- Check journal policy via [SHERPA/RoMEO](https://v2.sherpa.ac.uk/romeo/)

**Published Version**: Final formatted article

- Usually requires payment or agreements

</details>

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-piggy-bank"></i> Managing Costs</summary>

**Free Options:**

- Submit preprints to discipline servers
- Upload postprints to institutional repository

**Funded Options:**

- Check institutional agreements
- Contact LMU Open Access: [open-access@ub.uni-muenchen.de](mailto:open-access@ub.uni-muenchen.de)
- Request CC BY for maximum reusability

</details>

### Identifiers & Licensing

Ensuring findability and reuse.

::: {.orc-grid-feature}

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-fingerprint"></i> ORCID

Your unique researcher identifier:

- Links all publications and datasets
- Persists across institutions
- Create free at [orcid.org](https://orcid.org/)
:::

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-link-45deg"></i> DOI

Digital Object Identifiers:

- Assigned by repositories
- Required for citation
- Enables impact tracking
:::

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-database-lock"></i> Data Licenses

Recommended:

- **CC0**: Maximum reusability
- **CC BY 4.0**: Attribution required
- Avoid CC BY-NC (limits reuse)
:::

::: {.orc-card-feature}
### <i class="bi bi-code-slash"></i> Code Licenses

Common choices:

- **MIT**: Permissive, widely adopted
- **Apache 2.0**: Patent protection
- **GPL-3.0**: Derivatives must be open
:::

:::

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-people"></i> Author Contributions</summary>

Use [CRediT taxonomy](https://credit.niso.org/) to specify contributions:

- Conceptualization, Data curation, Formal analysis
- Methodology, Software, Visualization
- Writing (original draft, review & editing)

Benefits: transparent contribution tracking, proper attribution, career development.

</details>

:::

## <i class="bi bi-check2-square"></i> Preservation Checklist

::: {.orc-gradient-box}

**Before Publication:**

- [ ] Data deposited in appropriate repository with metadata
- [ ] Code published on GitHub with documentation and license
- [ ] DOIs obtained for data and code
- [ ] All authors have ORCIDs linked
- [ ] Licenses applied (CC0/CC BY for data, MIT/Apache for code)
- [ ] Sensitive data removed and anonymization verified
- [ ] Ethics approval for data sharing if required

**At Submission:**

- [ ] Data Availability Statement includes all DOIs
- [ ] Code availability and reproducibility materials linked
- [ ] Manuscript links to ORCID, ROR, funder IDs
- [ ] Author contributions specified using CRediT
- [ ] Open access option selected if available

**After Acceptance:**

- [ ] Postprint uploaded to institutional repository
- [ ] Preprint updated with link to published version
- [ ] Repository READMEs updated with publication citation
- [ ] Co-authors receive final citation and PDF

**Long-term:**

- [ ] Verify DOIs resolve correctly
- [ ] Respond to data/code access requests
- [ ] Monitor citations and usage metrics

:::
